captions.text: Phoenix_fire asks:
Now I want to know about sexuality in Korea.
And she’s not the only person who wants to know about it
Because we got
FOUR HUNDRED THUMBS UP FOR THAT QUESTION
I think that’s the most thumbs up we’ve ever received
For a question.
ACTUALLYYYY,
Four hundred and three
So we’re gonna be foreigners here
And be very open about a subject
That’s not very open in Korea.
Were also only going to be telling you
What other people have told us about the subject
Because we ourselves
Haven’t had sex with Korean people.
So we cant really speak on
First term experience.
And were really only talking about experiences from our friends.
So talking about sexuality with my girlfriends
is kind of an awkward subject
Because in Canada, you might ask your friends like
Oh, did you kiss yet,
What base did you get to
What BASE did you get to?!
What is this like grade 6?
There’s nothing wrong with bases! It’s a perfectly
Good way to describe your sexual fartherness.
First base is hand holding,
Maybe some touching,
Second base is kissing, and, groping maybe,
Third base is really grope-sing and stuff
And then home run is sexy times.
Doesn’t anyone else use that?
I still use bases.
Like I have friends who are just like
Did you f#$% her yet
Gasp! You can’t say that word!
It sounds like a sheep!
Anyways,
So my girlfriends and I might giggle and talk about stuff like that,
But in Korea unless you’re very very very very
close with your girlfriend
You don’t really talk about it that much
And it might be not very detailed –
“Did you boom boom jiggity jiggity yes no wink twice if you did yes”
I want to give an easy example of sex and sexuality not coming up a lot
So in university that’s the time period in Canada where
You’re gonna have sexuality pushed on you the most
In the sense of
You need to use protection
Do you know what kind of STDs you can get
You can have sex and DIE
Here’s lube
Here are all the birth control pills you should be on
Like it’s very much talked about
Because they assume that people are
starting to have sex at this age
But in Korea there is no talk about this
Like there are no bags of condoms
Like, nailed onto the dorm room
What kind of college did you go to?!
My college didn’t have bags of condoms everywhere!
Listen!
I didn’t go to a dorm
I lived at home with my parents in my basement
So I didn’t experience that
But I’ve heard
That friends that were in dorms
Had like the
“Here’s like the communal condom bag”
that people should take condoms from
and if you go to the doctor in your university
she’ll say to you like
“Are you sexually active?
Are you on birth control?
Here are birth controls you should be on”
And girls
Will openly talk about it
You’re like “What kind of birth control are you on?”
“I’m on this kind, I’m on that kind”
But in Korea
My Korean friends
Said that they don’t know anybody on birth control.
That’s weird why won't people be on birth control here?
I mean I think birth control can be for different things
It can be for like acne, or cramps, or it could be for sex,
But I think that—
Or for controlling birth.
Hence the NAME, birth control.
But if you go on birth control for sex,
You have to be
Thinking that you’re going to have sex
Sex with you’re randomly, or
Sex with your--
Sex! Sex! Sex on the beach!
What’s that song?
This conversation is becoming that awkward conversation
That you have with your parents
That everyone’s behind the computer right now
Going AHHH
Why am I watching this, please stop
Listen, when a girl and a boy like each other,
Oh man.
I feel awkward for you people watching this
These are the ovaries,
All I’m saying is that people don’t talk about sex.
If you’re a girl in Korea
But the guys are like,
“Hey, how about that girl that we met
at that massage parlor last night? Looking at you Simon”
Ok now when I was teaching at an all girls’ High school,
I remember something that really stood out in my mind.
Um, besides showing Mirotic to them
Which went over really badly,
And their ovaries exploded simultaneously,
No, I showed them Twilight.
And there’s a scene in the very first Twilight
Where Edward is in the woods with Kristin Stewart
Why cant I remember her actual Twilight name?
Its alligator! Idk. Whatever
And he goes like this up to her like this
And everyone like screamed in the class
And my students were definitely, like 17.
And that kind of like close-proximity
Face mushing was very much like
AHHHH-AHHH excitement
Because!
I had like two students that had boyfriends
Out of like ALLL of my thirteen classes of like
40 students, two of them had boyfriends.
And I never see teenagers making out in Korea.
Have you noticed?
Well, I haven’t seen teenagers making out in Korea
But I know that
In Hongdae, like in the area that we’re in
The college area, like in the club district
You do see people like on a Friday and Saturday night
Oh yeah, Getting drunk and making out.
There’s a --
Our stairwell is like the make out stairwell
Because it’s all like dark and sexy
It’s right by the toilets where you can smell everything
The motion sensors
I remember we were like walking through Hongdae
And there was this coffee shop
And instead of you go upstairs
You go through this like
Pointing downstairs
You could look down from the street
And you could see like the people
In the coffee shop
And it was pretty late at night
And there was this one guy
REALLY trying to make out with this girl
And he was like, over the table like
All like this,
Like all up in her face
And what not and really trying to like
Touch her and grab her and whatnot
And I remember standing outside the window with our friend Ryan
And I was like, “Let’s see if we can make them
Uncomfortable.”
And we stood there staring at them
and stared at them until the girl
Finally looked over and went
“AHH!”
And we walked away
And then we gave them a thumbs up
Us foreigners approve
Of your, getting jiggity with it.
We don’t want to make it seem like this is
A hedonistic cesspool of which there are like
Orgies happening in the streets
But we have noticed people making out.
Yeah people will make out its not like Korean people are just,
And not like slow motion with cameras panning around them
With three time replays and none of that
Its just like, people kiss each other. True.
If you want to take it to the next level,
After you’ve done your kissing
You can—“Is the next level playing Twister?”
No.
The next level is having sex.
Ohhhhhhhhh.
And if you want to do that
You can go to Love Motels in Korea
And these are pretty interesting,
Institutions that you have there.
There are actual motels which
Are pretty much known for
If you wanna have sexy time
So you can rent them
You can even rent them by the hour
Depending on how efficient you are with your time!
You can be like “five minutes is all I need, son!”
You can rent it by the hour, you can rent it by the day
And it’s not something where you usually go to
And you spend like, a week there
There’s not gonna be like a breakfast place
Or a concierge,
I can’t say that word
You’re going there, because
You mean to have sex,
And its like the windows are tinted
There are even like,
If you drive up there, then they have these little
Dangly, tassels, so that you cant see the drivers faces
As they’re going in
Or for like the people getting out of the car
You can’t see them.
Because we went to some of them a couple times
When we were travelling around Korea
WOO!!
FOR TRAVELLING purposes. Yeah,
But I would like to add here
That there are love motels
That people go to to actually stay in
Because it’s cheap
So if you’re coming to Korea
And you don’t want to go to hostel
Or you don’t want to go to like the Hilton
You can go to love motel!
It’s got a bed and a bathtub,
And MOOD LIGHTING!
And you might know it’s a love motel
Because we’ve seen some
Vending machines in which you can purchase
Dildi. That’s pluralization of dildo.
And condoms, and like lube. Yes, it has it all there.
We didn’t know in our first year
That these were love motels.
Until we walked down the hallway
And were like, “I am, suspicious”
If you are, dating a Korean guy,
There are more smooth and subtle
Pick up lines.
Like for example,
They will say,
Remember this ladies!
If a Korean guy asks you if you want to go on a
“Day Trip”
It doesn’t mean that he wants to go camping
But it means that he might be pitching a tent
Somewhere else.
Wha- what do you mean, I don’t know what you mean.
I don’t know, I don’t have any money.
It’s a euphemism for,
“Lets go somewhere—
and have a sexy trip?
That’s right.
It could be day trip, could be.
To a location,
And then there could be love motel there as well.
Eyebrow raising. Can anyone see our eyebrows?
We’re gonna talk a lot more about the
Why of love motels and the whole
Interesting-ness behind them in
Our blog post, so
Click the link here if you want to check that out
And learn more about it.
Yess, love motels.
I think we’ve been to like three.
One of them had a soft,
Like a really soft foamy mattress.
And the other one
I was scared to use the hot tub.
I’m like “I don’t know what’s happened in here..”
All I know is that if CSI came up in there
With a black light
It would be like disco.
DOO DOO DOO DOO BLEEW BLEE (DISCO SOUNDS)
Yep, semen.
Semen, everywhere semen. There it is, up, yep, there’s….
So that’s it for this week’s TL;DR if you have a question
for next TL;DR leave your question in the comment section below.
Or you can check out the
Questions already asked and you can thumb them up
To get them to our attention
And don’t forget to subscribe for more TL;DRs
Where we talk about nasty sexuality.
Sexual seduction. Ask us about starfish.
Tell me what you want. Hey hey hey!
Tell me do you want me, nah nah.
Speaking of sex, you know what’s sexy?
Ooooh, is it fundraising?
It is fundraising.
Ooooh, and this Saturday, July 6, 2013
We’re going to be doing some sexy fundraising
In Itaewon.
From 7 to 10pm, this Saturday
In Botton café in Itaewon,
Were gonna be helping
Liberty in North Korea
Which is an NGO that helps North Korean refugees.
They’re renting out a photo booth,
And for a small donation you can
Come out, and you can take pictures,
With us, in the photo booth,
Or if you don’t really like us or care about us,
You can just take photos with your friends,
That’s cool man.
The goal is to raise donations!
Its all for a very good cause, yes.
I think it’s really worth it
Were putting ourselves behind it
We hope you can come out as well
And help support the cause
And were going to include a link here that you can
Click on and it will give you more information
On how to get there
So be sure to check it out
We’d love to see you there this Saturday. Yess!
undefined

+8luvbug South Korea as whole has been more accepting then any country in 
the world when it comes to homosexuality from like 2007 - 2013 there has

while 70% are not/have a bit of discomfort so you cant say all of them are 
against it with out actual facts (which in your statement those facts don't 
exist)....btw for those who are gay and want to be open i guess in korea 
the best Place is Seoul which is more or less like NY in the United 
states....But anyways Seoul or anywhere near Seoul (the only one that comes 
ot mind is Itaewon) are very much accepting of homosexuality  ( I would say 
it's more like 40%/100% of korean are perfectly or dont care if your gay or 
not) there so accepting in Seoul to the point where Koreans had there very 
first Pride in Seoul

comments.text:
My understanding of 'sexuality' was that it referred to whether you're gay 
or straight or bisexual, asexual etc. this video was interesting but I'm 
now interested in how Korea treats gay people, expectations of getting 
married etc. etc.﻿
comments.author: LisaJoan

comments.text:
+LisaJoan
 I totally understand that cultures often misuse words. I was just trying 
to be informative. ^-^
comments.author: LeDubKitty

comments.text:
I'm sorry for misunderstanding, but it's just that the term is generally 
used for describing a person's sexual orientation in my culture. I was also 
just interested in finding out about Korea's views on that topic as well. 
However, I am not an idiot for misinterpreting a term for how it is used in 
my culture because it is different from the way that you understand it. 
Please try to be sensitive to people's feelings and help to educate rather 
than put down.
comments.author: LisaJoan

comments.text:
+LeDubKitty Thank you. So many idiots in the comments saying "I thought 
this was going to be about LGBT herp derp"

turns out, the people who really want them to discuss that aren't very 
educated, if they think sexuality instantly means gay/lesbian/etc.
comments.author: Ausar0

comments.text: +LisaJoan Sexuality is a lot more broad than sexual orientation.

comments.text:

comments.author: SpokaneJohn

comments.text:
in the TL;DR they actually said that the younger crowd, 25 and under, tend 
to be fairly accepting.
senior citizens view it as a "foreign disease" - or at least, that was what 
one really close-minded school principal their friend talked to said.
im transgendered and pansexual, but i've had multiple living arrangements, 
sometimes with people who knew and were cool with it, and a few 
circumstances with people who weren't. my advice to anyone, from ANY 
country, is to protect yourself first. i dont know your orientation, but 
this is especially true if you're bi or trans, because some people who are 
accepting of some lgbt people hold certain biases against other lgbt 
people. many people who support lesbians and gay men still look down upon 
bisexuals, pansexuals, and trans people. biphobia and transphobia is 
actually a lot more common, even, than homophobia.
at my last workplace, i had several gay coworkers, so i thought maybe i 
could at least come out to them as pan. i...steered the conversation to 
imply that i supported bisexual people, and i was shocked by their negative 
remarks.
so that's what i recommend, if youre thinking of coming out to people on 
your trip, or to the friends you make there. find ways to steer the 
conversation, then ask for their opinion.
